Award.AwardTitle: Studies in Nuclear Physics and Fundamental Interactions at Indiana University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for activities of the Indiana University nuclear physics group, addressing the following critical scientific questions: (a) How is the angular momentum, or spin, of the proton distributed among its internal quark and gluon constituents? We know that the spin of the quarks does not add up to make the spin of the proton, so maybe the quarks are orbiting around inside the proton or maybe the so-called "gluons", the particles the bind the quarks together inside the proton, possess some spin. (b) Why did the Big Bang leave the universe with the surplus of matter over anti-matter that we see today? Using a connection derived theoretically by the famous Soviet physicist Andrei Sakharov, we will address this question by looking for interactions in Nature which change upon reversal of the direction of time (c) Do neutrinos, the lightest and most weakly interacting massive particles known in nature, behave strangely at low energy? We will use a special beam constructed at Fermilab to check. (d) How strong is the weak force inside and between neutrons and protons? We will perform precise measureements using slow neutron beams to answer this.

The broader impacts of our group's activities begin locally through our contributions to the human and technological infrastructure of the Indiana University Cyclotron Facility, which applies proton accelerators to radiotherapy for cancer treatment, tests the effects of radiation on biological systems and electronics, and makes slow neutrons for materials research. These activities have created two new local companies. Our research activities also educate the next generation of skilled and innovative PhD scientists for jobs in research and teaching universities, industry and national labs, and medical and computer technology. We host summer schools, develop undergraduate laboratories emphasizing nuclear technology, and assist with programs that encourage pre-college participation in the Indiana University science curriculum. We reach out to the local community through a variety of activities that awaken the interest of students in our local public school system. We actively recruit female and minority applicants for positions at all levels within the group, and work to make our activities known to the public at large through laboratory tours and Open Houses, science café discussions, and items of public interest in the media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The nuclear physics group at Indiana University has made significant progress in answering important scientific questions involving the strong nuclear force and in searching for possible new interactions in Nature. We concentrated our efforts on experiments that directly address these four key areas of inquiry:

(1) How do the quarks and gluons that make up the proton contribute to its observable properties? We used signals from a large detector we built earlier and installed in a detector at Brookhaven National Lab to show that the gluons in the proton are not spinning. We also developed new ways to measure the spin of the quarks and antiquarks which are confined inside the proton. 

(2) How do neutrinos ‘oscillate’ into different types and interact with matter? Are neutrinos and antineutrinos really the same? We measured neutrinos of different types turning into each other using both neutrino and antineutrino beams from Fermilab. We measured the probability for neutrinos to create reactions in carbon nuclei and discovered a 30% higher rate than predicted by theory. In an underground lab in New Mexico, we helped prepare a sensitivie search for a rare decay of an isotope of xenon that emits no neutrinos:  this can only happen if neutrinos and antineutrinos are really the same. 

(3) Can we find evidence for an electric dipole moment in a fundamental particle, a result that would require violating some of the most basic symmetries of nature? An electric dipole moment, which comes from a separation of positive and negative electric charge, is forbidden for fundamental particles unless the laws of physics depend on the direction of flow of time. We prepared for future experiments in the neutron and electron.

(4) How can we use the strong nuclear force to unravel the details of much weaker forces? We searched for violations of mirror symmetry at the NIST lab near Washington DC by looking to see if spinning neutrons would corkscrew while moving through liquid helium. We searched the debris from collisions of large nuclei made by an accelerator at Brookhaven to see if there are any signs of mirror asymmetries and saw some hints which we are trying to either comfirm or reject. We discovered new ways to slow down neutrons at the neutron source at Los Alamos National Lab which will allow us to conduct many precise experiments. We measuerd the protons and electrons in neutron decay at NIST to determine the relative odds that they are emitted in the same or opposite directions.

In addition to these scientific results, we also in parallel developed new technologies to improve our ability to perform more precise experiments in the future. Examples of these new technologies include better ways to detect neutrinos and high energy neutrons and more efficient electronics to process the required information, electrically quiet high voltage sources, extremely low-noise computer data acquisition systems, and more precise ways to track electrically-charged particles in head-to-head collisions of high energy protons.  

The Indiana nuclear physics group has a long tradition of training outstanding undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdocs who succeed both as scientific researchers and educators and also in professional roles in the private sector.  Over the last three years seven IU students received their Ph.D. degrees.  Of the seven, four are now postdoctoral research associates at universities or national labs, two are employed in the private sector in energy-related areas, and one works for the American Physical Society in physics education and outreach. Roughly a third of our students are recipients of either national or university-wide awards or fellowships.
